body:
Thanks a lot. 
Can I use a macro to specify the log filepath as attachment in EmailOperator ? 
Something like `{{ ti.log_filepath }}`
I'm closing as the fix has been merged to master

This was a `PATH` issue :) In case anyone experiences this, my path was correctly set in `/etc/environment/` but this wasn't picked up at boot hence not being able to find the airflow binary.

I amended my users profile to set the path.

We don't use that feature at Airbnb so we probably won't work on it. But from a design perspective you could have a read only table above the current crud section. We'll be happy to review a PR doing this.
Yup, it should work.

Good catch, looks like a legit bug. Can you please paste the full stacktrace? 

Looks like we just need to cast to datetime somewhere in that view.
I meant to do this and never got to it. Thanks again for the post.

Looks like this commit fixed the problem: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/c4d0fe93ed8185114364984e5eafa1b1fc404a0c#diff-6ff6b61554e53188d97c129ed40256cd
However it's not part of the package that `pip install` picks up (code still lists itself as v. 1.6.1).

I did a `pip install -U git+https://github.com/airbnb/airflow@master`. Restarted the webserver and the scheduler, but now the scheduler fails with:

Tried `airflow resetdb` but still get the error above. However now the scheduler does run, but the error shows up occasionally.
Also `airflow upgradedb` didn't change anything.
Time is probably ripe for 1.6.2
We typically recommend using config var (env variables) when working with anything connection related on Heroku. That's how we connect to other dbs when using Airflow. I'd love to see this too.

@mistercrunch Seeing #756, I can easily add tests for this. It can be done using `mock` to mock `docker.Client` or testing against a running instance of the Docker daemon. What is the preferred way for airflow?

ETL or batch processing in the data world is often differential loads. Each run loads a specific time period. So you may want to backfill, in which case there's a backfill command in the CLI.

You can also set the start_date at the DAG level or for each task. 

For the example we set the start_date a week in the past so that we can demonstrate how the scheduler works and how it can catch up.
There's also externally triggered DAG if your workload isn't not on a schedule.

@wndhydrnt @mistercrunch to chime in on your question: travis does not allow docker-in-docker at the moment so my suggestion would be to use mock. Using travis' VMs (by using sudo: required) would significantly slow down the testing speed for a non core feature.
@mistercrunch Added code.rst update. Imported contrib.hooks in models.py. Please have another look.

I didn't try `password_auth.py` before, but if LDAP authentication is within your consideration, you can  set it up by following steps:

1) Set up a LDAP server:

https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-install-and-configure-a-basic-ldap-server-on-an-ubuntu-12-04-vps

2) Select `ldap_auth.py` as your authentication backend.
3) Add LDAP configs in `airflow.cfg`:

```
bind_user = cn=admin,dc=vagrant,dc=com
bind_password = ????
uri = ldap://127.0.0.1:389
user_filter = objectClass=posixAccount
user_name_attr = cn
basedn = dc=vagrant,dc=com
```

But I am also curious about how to use password_auth.py as backend. Appreciated if anyone could help :D

Hi Wesley,

Note that if you create a PythonOperator and set the parameter `provide_context` to `True`, you will get the context of the task instance provided to you.
In particular in the context dict, you get `execution_date`, which is the `datetime` object corresponding to 2015-12-01 00:00:00 for instance. 

I hope this helps.

The `context` dictionary made available to your templates is also made available to all operators' `execute` method. As @artwr said, it's also available to your python callable when using the PythonOperator

Along the same vein as the original post, here's another limbo case.

I have a task with two parents. The task's `trigger_rule` is `all_success`. One of the parents succeeded but the other parent was marked as `upstream_failed`. This task is never scheduled.

``` python
- elif failed + upstream_failed >= len(task._upstream_list):
+ elif (failed + upstream_failed >= len(task._upstream_list) or
+   (task.trigger_rule == TR.ALL_SUCCESS and upstream_failed > 0)):
```
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/718
This code does not fully solve the problem. I am going to keep working and will notify when the fix actually works.
I met the same issue. I found that some execution files was placed in `/usr/local/bin`, after `export PATH=/usr/local/bin:$PATH`, everything is fine, you could have a try.

You can do that by adding a root task all the way downstream, and adding a `ExternalTaskSensor` referencing it as a dependency for all leaf nodes (most upstream) for the previous run.

You could also reduce the `max_active_runs` of your DAG to limit the parallelism all the way to 1.
thanks for jumping in @lukun2010 !

Can you provide an example for our DAG in the Graph view above? As mentioned, essentially, for use-case 2, we want `clear spark logs` for a DAG run to wait until the previous run's `send_email_notification_flow_successful` completes successfully.
@jthomas123, thanks for the PR, but it looks like it isn't python 3 compatible, let me add a comment in the code

Look at how ExternalTaskSensor has an `execution_delta` param. You can just have one task directly upstream of `clear spark logs` that targets  the same dag_id, and `send_email_notification_flow_successful` for `execution_delta=dag.schedule_interval`
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#airflow.operators.ExternalTaskSensor
Yeah I ended up merging a fix today. I'll make sure it makes the next pypi version
Yeah there's probably more of those... Until we find something more generic I'll just merge it in.

Cool. Didn't think about using it within the same DAG. Thx. Will try that out. I am running hourly, so I could set the execution delta to `hours=1`. Is the execution delta a minimum requirement or a maximum requirement? In other words, does at least 1 hour difference need to occur for the trigger to fire? Or does the trigger fire up until a max difference of 1 hour occurs?
Logging is still busted in master. Running `airflow run` doesn't create a file.

@mistercrunch When you say "create a file" what file are you expecting? Are we talking logs out of the executor? 

If so, that's something we also noticed after this fix went in - the scheduler is producing logs but not the celery executors. If that's not what you mean, let me know.
A better approach would be to set defaults to `None` in airflow/configuration.py

The worker wasn't generating log files. Each task instance is supposed to have a log file on the worker.
This addresses it:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/3be5e81154728a7fa2ca5c7072e3ba8b9750d9f1

The problem is around the fact that basicConfig can't be called twice, or handles need to get reset. After reading a bit about it, it seems like the current approach is bad because if someone was to import airflow from another module it would reset their handlers.

Check out the section about `baseConfig`, especially the line that goes "This function does nothing if the root logger already has handlers configured for it."

Ah, of course.  I hadn't realised (until looking earlier) that there was a Python default as well.  I'll close this PR and raise a new one with a clean branch (BTW I had to use an empty string rather than None)
raised #773
Good catch on the fix. I think we'll want to iterate on a slightly more elegant solution, but I'm not quite sure what that is yet.
Yeah, first we need a unit test that makes sure `airflow run` outputs where expected.
Thanks for the PR
Can we tag whoever shows up in git blame for that line?

You'll need to log into the box where airflow is installed and open up a new python repl. Then import the airflow libs and then create a new PasswordUser. Once you've created that first user, you can then create other users via the web interface.

Here's an example:

```
$ cd ~/airflow
$ python
Python 2.7.9 (default, Feb 10 2015, 03:28:08) 
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 6.0 (clang-600.0.56)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import airflow
>>> from airflow import models, settings
>>> from airflow.contrib.auth.backends.password_auth import PasswordUser
>>> user = PasswordUser(models.User())
>>> user.username = 'new_user_name'
>>> user.email = 'new_user_email@example.com'
>>> user.password = 'set_the_password'
>>> session = settings.Session()
>>> session.add(user)
>>> session.commit()
>>> session.close()
>>> exit()
```

I'll write these instructions in the documentation. I originally thought of creating a new user with a password in the migrations but I didn't want to have the risk of developers installing airflow and not deleting that default account.
May I ask which version of airflow you are using? I think this has been fixed in master.

Good to know about the `provide_context`. Sorry, I didn't saw.

Thanks for the answers guys! 

Surely in the roadmap we aim to have the most tasks using PythonOperator. But I think I'm given one step higher than the leg putting everything in PythonOperators.

We are still understanding the options that we have with Airflow. Aiming a soft transition, we actually need to keep the things running on their bashs scripts and later transform in PythonOperators.

I guess the right question should be something like "How to modify the BashOperator task's context"

I will open another issue :)

It looks like the logging is currently having issues indirectly related to s3 whereby the "os.path.exists" call right after "import boto" is returning False in the current master. It seems like the files are never being created.

I have rebased this branch back to an older version that was working for us.
thanks!

This PR is currently working to fix the s3:/ issue relating to a misuse of lstrip but there are other issues present in master which are preventing the log files from being written in the first place.

Check out the `env` parameter in BashOperator
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/_modules/bash_operator.html#BashOperator

I just added a PR (https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/776/files) to make this parameter templated, meaning the values of the dict can receive jinja as in `env = {'execution_date': "{{ execution_date.isoformat() }}"}` and will get replaced at runtime.

Here's the list of what you can use:
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#macros

@mistercrunch I think that's happening because airflow is configuring logging in two places. Is that necessary?

We've iterated a lot on our logging, and ended up implementing something similar to this: http://victorlin.me/posts/2012/08/26/good-logging-practice-in-python. It now works very well, although took a while to get there. The key issues were to isolate what we wanted to change (i.e. don't touch the root logger, decide whether you want to set handlers or leave that up to the user, etc), and have a single place to set the logging config. 

Over the holidays I could have a go at implementing this is airflow. @mistercrunch let me know if that would be congruent with airflow goals and whether you have any high level requirements. 

One thing to note: we currently implement the logging config in a YAML file. The `fileConfig` (which is the format airflow's config currently uses) for logging has less functionality than the `dictConfig` (which can take a YAML or JSON file). But I'm not sure whether you'd want different formats for different config files.
@MaximilianR That sounds about right. It would be nice to keep it overridable in the way it is now for people who don't want to have to set up a file-based config but yes.

I tried the `env` parameter, but today I can't update the values at runtime.

If I understood, after the PR be merged I will be able to do:

``` python
from airflow.operators import BashOperator

customEnv = {
'date_ini': "{{ execution_date.isoformat() }}", 
'date_end': "{{ execution_date + dag.schedule_interval }}"
}
env = dict(os.environ, **customEnv)
task = BashOperator(
            ...
            env=env
        )

# on the etl scripts
import os 
...
date_ini = os.getenv('date_ini')
date_end = os.getenv('date_end')
...
```
Exactly, I just merged the PR

Have you thought about using a `contextmanager` to handle these? http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/orm/session_basics.html#when-do-i-construct-a-session-when-do-i-commit-it-and-when-do-i-close-it

For example:

``` python
@contextmanager
def session_scope(session_cls):
    """Provide a transactional scope around a series of operations."""
    session = session_cls()
    try:
        yield session
        session.commit()
    except Exception, e:
        logger.exception(e)
        session.rollback()
        raise
    finally:
        session.close()
```

Then in the code:

``` python
with Session() as session:
    # ...
    session.add(Log(State.SUCCESS, self))
    # ...
```

Then when you exit the `with` statement, your session is cleaned up, and the code writing to the DB doesn't need to worry about closing sessions / connections / handling exceptions / etc - it's all abstracted.

It turns out close connections in sqla doesn't actually close them, it releases them to the connection pool when using one. `engine.dispose()` seems like the way to go according to this:
http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/connections.html#engine-disposal

I ran Airflow against a real ActiveDirectory install, and it didn't work. Our settings were:

```
uri = ldap://<ip>:<port>
user_filter = objectClass=*
user_name_attr = sAMAccountName
bind_user = <user>@<foo.com>
bind_password = ******
basedn = dc=foo,dc=bar
```

This failed with a `KeyError['dn'] not found` exception. Removing the search_scope=LEVEL fixed this. We are now able to log in with LDAP using this patch.

cc @bolkedebruin

The external task sensor with an external_dag_id of the same dag worked well. Thanks for pointing out that operator!

Example:

```
wait_for_task_in_previous_hour = ExternalTaskSensor(
    task_id='wait_for_task_in_previous_hour',
    external_dag_id='my_dag_id',
    external_task_id='task_to_wait_for_id',
    allowed_states=['success'],
    execution_delta=timedelta(hours=1),
    dag=dag)
```

Hi @Tjorriemorrie
Without knowing the exact details of your problem, I'll try to answer what I think your issue is.
I've found the following works.

Let's say that you have a DAG file `my_first_dag.py` that is imported by both the scheduler and webserver. At Agari, we use local executors and run a single scheduler with local executors as well as the webserver on the same (single) EC2 instance. 

Let's also say that your dag_id is `my_first_dag_v1`. You can always wipe out your old DAG and its history while simultaneously importing a new DAG by 1) changing `my_first_dag_v1` to `my_first_dag_v2` in your `my_first_dag.py` file and 2) restarting both webserver and scheduler. The result will be a new DAG with no history and the name of the DAG (i.e. the dag_id) will now be `my_first_dag_v2`.

If you ever want to change the name of a DAG file, then you should change both the dag_id and the DAG file name. If you just change the DAG file name, but keep the dag_id the same, there will be a problem. 

So, in the example above, your new file and dag_id could be `blah_blah_dag.py` and `blah_blah_dag_v1`, respectively.

Try `airflow clear data_pipeline -s 2015-10-22 -e 2015-10-22` if you just want to clear one day. If you want to clear more than one day, then try something like `airflow clear data_pipeline -s 2015-10-22 -e 2015-10-24`. If you run an hourly DAG, then you can also do `airflow clear data_pipeline -s 2015-10-22T00:00:00 -e 2015-10-22T23:00:00` to clear 24 hours for one day.
